bibl.title: Letter from Sarah Hinds Wilder to Henry Rose Carter, November 19, 1915

div1.p: Wilder expresses her appreciation for Carter's work.

div1.head: Letter from Sarah Hinds Wilder to Henry Rose Carter, November 19, 1915
div1.opener:
1895 Thorburn Avenue
Portland - Oregon-
Dr. Henry R. Carter-
Dear Sir-
div1.p:
No doubt- among the hun-
dreds you have befriended-
you have forgotten me long
ago- I was a Massachusetts
woman - whose husband died
of Yellow Fever in 1900 - at the
Hotel Yumari on Aguiar Street
in Habana- Later I had the
fever in the house of a family
named Janetti on Cuba Street.
I met you on both occasions-

Perhaps you may re
member the preparation for-
and the shipment of my husband's
body home- I have never forgotten
your wonderful kindness on that
occasion- Many times-when I have
read of the remarkable things- ac-
complished by some of the “figure-heads”
of the Health Department. I have won-
dered whether-or not-you still might
be furnishing the motive power in the
background- So- when I saw in this
morning's paper that you had been
very ill- I wanted to write and tell
you that I am thankful the world
has had the blessing of your life
and work during all these
years - and that I hope - if it is
God's will- you may recover-

I believe History will find a place
for such as you and Dr- Finlay
more lasting than that of many
a man - who has destroyed great
opportunities for doing good in fur-
nishing the fuel to keep the light
of his own popularity ablaze-

But after all the conscious-
ness of having been instru-
mental in doing so much
C1
B20
for the permanent benefit
of humanity must be
your greatest reward-
div1.closer: Very sincerely your friend Sarah Hinds Wilder November 19th 1915
